Page Title: Conducting the immigration experience â€” Ramiro Roballos' journey from symphony to startup
Meta Description: Discover the motivations and pivotal moments that led to the creation of Tukki, a platform revolutionizing the US immigration experience.
H1: Conducting the immigration experience â€” Ramiro Roballos' journey from symphony to startup
All Headings:
H1: Conducting the immigration experience â€” Ramiro Roballos' journey from symphony to startup
H2: Saying yes to the plunge
H2: Losing 5 months, but gaining a mission
H2: Tukki today
Main Content: Conducting the immigration experience â€” Ramiro Roballos' journey from symphony to startup US IMMIGRATION, BUT SIMPLE. Conducting the immigration experience â€” Ramiro Roballos' journey from symphony to startup Contributor Nadine Heir Reading time 8 mins read Date published Jun 30, 2024 Tap into the wealth of experience and unique perspective that having previously worked as a McKinsey consultant and an orchestra conductor brings to this story. In this exclusive Q&A, Ramiro Roballos , CEO of Tukki, delves into the pivotal moments and motivations that led him to create the groundbreaking platform turning the US immigration process into a premium experience. Drawing from his own challenging experiences with immigration and his passion for technology, Ramiro shares the journey from his initial "Eureka" moment to winning a Hackathon in Austin and partnering with former colleagues to build a solution that addresses the real pain points of migrants. This in-depth conversation reveals not only the origins of Tukki but also the mission-driven approach that continues to shape its development and impact following Ramiroâ€™s interview with me, your line into Tukki's secrets, Nadine Heir . Saying yes to the plunge Q: Where did the â€œTukki Eurekaâ€ moment come from? A: Iâ€™d been working at McKinsey in Miami before, a truly consuming job where I learned an immense amount, fed my MBA experience, and flexed my business muscles. I had an itch to start something of my own though, to learn how to code, and get back to leading something bigger than me â€” like I did as an orchestra conductor and at my music school in Argentina â€” and knew I couldnâ€™t do that while working as a consultant. So I took the plunge, I left the company with no plan B. I was saying â€œyesâ€ to all the potential ideas and adventures that crossed my path. I had continued studying programming on weekends and in May of 2023, I went to a Techstars Hackathon in Austin to present myself as a programmer, not a McKinsey consultant for the first time. So you see, I already had this idea in mind. I knew there was a gap in the market because Iâ€™d been through the literal nightmare that was US immigration in the most traditional sense. Itâ€™s so old school and has not advanced at the rate of other industries that grow technology. I was ready to change that. Q: Did the Hackathon reveal demand in the market for your idea? A: In short, yes. Perhaps it was a sign that another group of programmers wanted to do something similar. We teamed up and pitched an AI-driven solution to immigration headaches and, out of around 30 teams, we won! I took this as a sign that the idea was more than valid. I was already talking to an old colleague from McKinsey, Saviley Vasilev, and essentially we decided to become partners, and founded Tukki . Losing 5 months, but gaining a mission Q: So tell us, what convinced you and your co-founder to join forces on this mission? A: The initial idea was to create a platform that would help lawyers. However, in-depth research revealed that lawyers werenâ€™t struggling with the process as much â€” to a certain extent, it â€œworkedâ€ for them. But it didnâ€™t work for migrants. In my own experience, Iâ€™ve never been more frustrated with a process. I was super keen to achieve my green card in 2021 when I was still at McKinsey, so was never taking longer than a 24h to complete my tasks as they came to me. Every copy, every form I had to get hold of, I had it within a day. But the lawyers I worked with would take 7 to 10 days to respond at each step. Even my critical questions would receive a sort of canned response, late, and unspecific. I lost 5 months of my life in the filing process. Then, the government took another 18 months to give me a response. Now, when I say I donâ€™t think immigration should be this hard â€” you know I mean it. I felt completely alone in the process, fed up, and very ready to flip the process on its head. By October 2023, I decided to incorporate Tukki with Saveliy Vasilev and supported by JosÃ© De Wit , our legal advisor who leads a team of lawyers and paralegals. We married the technological expertise with legal structure to make a solution that people really need. Tukki today Q: How does Tukki fit into your own life plans and aspirations? A: Bare minimum, I want to spend my life doing something that matters. It could be the most successful piece of technology, but whatever happens, I plan to enjoy this journey. And you know what, the feeling every time we achieve the â€œapprovedâ€ notification for an applicant, and they leave the consulate in the green, that feeling is like no other. If this interview inspired you, learn more about Ramiro by joining him on LinkedIn . And if youâ€™re curious what the Tukki teamâ€™s been building, check out our visa match tool . WE CAN HELP Need more clarity? Find quick answers to frequent visa questions from our legal experts Can I work while waiting for my green card approval? Yes, if you apply for and receive an Employment Authorization Document (EAD) as part of your Adjustment of Status. Without an EAD, you cannot work until your green card is approved, unless you already hold a valid work visa. Is health insurance in the US necessary to apply for a visa? Health insurance isnâ€™t necessary in order to obtain a visa in the US. However, it is recommended you plan for this expense for as soon as you arrive in the US. Can I switch employers while on an O-1 visa? Yes. You can change employers, but in most cases the new employer must file a new petition before you can begin working with them. The only exception is for O-1B visas filed through a U.S. agentâ€”in those cases, you may switch or add employers without needing to file a new petition. Can dependents of O-1 or H-1B visa holders attend public school in the U.S.? Yes. Children with O-3 or H-4 visas may attend public schools without additional authorization. How many pages should a petition have? A US visa application should be as few pages long as possible to thoroughly document your case. Avoid bulking up your case with evidence that repeats itself or adds minimal valueâ€”your lawyer can guide you in this sense. The forms alone take up 15-20 pages, and you will attach evidence and cover letters. Some petitions require more evidence than others. Tukkiâ€™s lawyers have seen many O-1A and EB-1A petitions that are as long as 400-1,000 pages, but EB-2 NIW applications that only required 200 pages to sufficiently document the case. For an applicant that received an enormous prize, an Oscar or Nobel prize for example, an O-1A application could be even fewer than 400 pages. Weâ€™ve also seen applicants sending more than 2,500 pages, but the length of a visa petition varies on a case by case basis. Main Content: Computer science, applied to US immigration â€” Saveliy Vasilev's story in Tukki US IMMIGRATION, BUT SIMPLE. Computer science, applied to US immigration â€” Saveliy Vasilev's story in Tukki Contributor Nadine Heir Reading time 8 mins read Date published Jul 22, 2024 In entrepreneurship, the way co-founders find each other sets the stage for the ventureâ€™s success, not only its inception. Saveliy Vasilev's path to founding Tukki is a testament to this. With a background rooted in computer science and academia, Saveliy transitioned to management consulting at McKinsey, seeking real-world business acumen, and it was here that he met Ramiro Roballos , a fellow consultant with a unique background in music. Their shared values and complementary skills forged a strong partnership, laying the foundation for what would become Tukki. This pivotal encounter underscores the importance of finding the right collaborator, as their combined expertise and vision are propelling them to create the premium US immigration experience. Q: What were you doing before Tukki â€” thinking about starting a business? A: I was thinking about starting a business even while I was doing my undergrad. In fact, even before that: when choosing what to study I thought about doing an undergrad in economics or business administration. But I finally opted for Computer science instead, and for a while I lived a mainly academic life: I had the opportunity to work in a lab, helping in what I could, and began growing closer to the faculty team whoâ€™d become my M.Sc. and PhD lecturers later. While I was in my first undergrad year, I attended a lecture given by Julian Mestre about Approximation Algorithms . At that time, I didnâ€™t understand much but found it very interesting. So a few years later, when finishing my undergrad I wrote to Julian, and asked him to be my Ph.D. advisor. It ended up being Julian Mestre (an Argentinean living in Australia), Min Chih Lin (a Taiwanese professor living in Argentina) advising myself (a Russian living in Argentina) â€” as international as it gets! We made it work and I spent 5 years researching problems and publishing articles on my chosen fascination. Moving the needle: Academia or entrepreneurship? After years in academia, by the time I was doing my PhD the idea of starting a business had cemented in my mind. I felt like I was on an intellectually exciting journey but I wanted to be able to say, â€œI gave something tangible to these specific peopleâ€, and for that something to be more than interesting publications. I recall thinking: the probability of me moving the needle in someoneâ€™s life doing science is much lower than doing so through the private enterprise. With that thought in mind towards the end of my doctoral program, I read a ton of books about the economy, history, business people, finance, etc. While that helped me build my own frameworks to think about life in general, the learning was still too conceptual and theoretical. So, equipped with a coordinate system that worked well for me, I decided that I had to get some real-life business skills before considering starting a venture by myself. â€œWhatâ€™s next after the dissertation?â€ I asked myself. Accelerated learning Moving from theory into action, I set out to find the best practical business experience I had within reach. I wrote to different people I knew had business experience to explore what options might be available to me. Among others, I was introduced to a director from Accenture, and while doing my homework before our meeting I got interested in consulting â€” not tech consulting but rather in management consulting: â€œat the end the day, these guys help senior folks through their toughest decisions, where else would I learn as fast?â€ I thought. Q: Where did you decide to boost your business acumen? A: Well, I Googled â€œwhat are the top management consulting firms,â€ and according to the search engine the answer was MBB, which stands for McKinsey, Bain and BCG. So I applied to McKinsey after a contact introduced me to a recruiter of theirs. They made me an offer and the learning journey began. The people, management and communication skills I learned there were invaluable to a nerd like me! During the consulting career one switches projects quite often and the teams one works with change as well. This allows one to develop a taste for management styles and ways of working. While with McKinsey I also met my now-co-founder of Tukki , Ramiro Roballos. He also has a non-traditional background compared to most consultants, with his career as an orchestra director and owner of a small music school. We clicked. We worked side-by-side for a client and we became close friends after many late hours at the clients offices. During our careers the growth we had as people and professionals was unmeasurable. The right person for the right venture Since those early days of our McKinsey careers, Ramiro and I spoke many times about doing something together. We shared key values including integrity, zero dishonesty tolerance, transparency, meritocracy; and that cascaded into our shared views on leadership style, what kind of organization we would like to be part of, and so on. I honestly cannot think of anyone better as a co-founder. And itâ€™s just as well â€” now we spend more time working on Tukki than with our families. Q: What convinced you to improve the immigration experience? A: As you can imagine we discussed many ideas before landing on immigration. One lesson I learned the hard way, before starting Tukki, is that building a business based on a â€œnice-to-haveâ€ idea is incredibly difficult: if you need to spend a lot of time convincing people to buy, however valuable your service or product is, then youâ€™re facing an uphill climb. Then came Ramiro, sharing his painful experience of obtaining his green card . Added to that, my recollections about my two immigration experiences werenâ€™t particularly fun either. So, as well-trained former consultants, we researched what the current state of affairs was and how to make it at least one order of magnitude better. An industry in dire need of an update The antiquated form in which people apply for visas is not only slow, US immigration processes leverages neither technology nor time-tested operational practices. Ramiro and I knew a thing or two about these topics, so we set out to make a dent in this field. Q: Whatâ€™s a vision of yours that youâ€™re applying in Tukki? A: I realized that each time I add value to someoneâ€™s life my happiness level increases. So doing that with people I enjoy working with and being able to sustain that in the long run is something I want for my life. Since we already had been in the trenches and had a lot of fun, I thought that jumping into some other trenches with Ramiro would be just as great. So we began to work on Tukki and take it as far as we can. At the time we said, if itâ€™s not the right route, weâ€™ll do something else. But the further we get into this venture, the more certain I am that weâ€™re changing the status-quo of how immigrants navigate the visa application â€” you know, thereâ€™s something beautiful when you see that smile on a clientsâ€™ face as a life-changing event happens: â€œItâ€™s approvedâ€, and the journey bringing them there was pleasant. We have a 100% success rate for visa acceptance â€” the relief and joy that applicants share with us when their visa is approved is incomparable. And no, we havenâ€™t served thousands of clients yet so that 100% might not last forever â€” but Iâ€™ll take pride in that nice round number while I can! Enjoy this? Connect with Saveliy on LinkedIn to see his story continue to unfold! WE CAN HELP Need more clarity? Find quick answers to frequent visa questions from our legal experts Can the employer change the job description or salary after recruitment begins? No. Once recruitment starts, the job requirements and prevailing wage cannot be changed without restarting the entire process from the beginning. What are the total costs of US immigration including legal fees, USCIS fees and any other payments? The total cost for US immigration varies depending on the type of visa and the number of applicants. On average, the all-inclusive cost ranges from $10,000 to $15,000 for a work visa and from $14,000 to $20,000 for a green card. For a family of four, the cost might range from $10,000 to $15,000 for a work visa and from $14,000 to $30,000 for a green card. To know the specific cost of your visa or green card application, consult our visa pricing calculator . How much documentation do I need to file a visa petition for an EB-1A or O-1A visa? In US immigration processes, your claims must be more likely than not to be true. This means if something appears more true than false, USCIS should accept it as true. To meet this standard, the visa petitioner should provide documents that convincingly support the claimâ€™s validity. For instance, to prove you received VC funding, you could provide signed SAFE agreements with a VC, a published article about your funding round, and documentation about the relevance of the VC. Keep in mind that theory and practice do not always perfectly align. Itâ€™s crucial you speak to an experienced legal team to avoid spending time and money on documentation that does not support your case. What is PERM? A PERM (Program Electronic Review Management) is a labor certification issued by the U.S. Department of Labor. It does NOT give immigration status. Instead, it confirms that no qualified and willing U.S. worker is available for the job and that the employer will pay at least the prevailing wage. It is the first step toward most EB-2 and EB-3 green cards. Do O-1 visas have a maximum number of years like H-1B? No. O-1 visas can be renewed indefinitely in increments (usually 1â€“3 years), as long as you continue to meet the criteria. Meta Description: Poor documentation control, archaic processes, and legal inefficiencies held this O-1 visa applicant back, until he found the premium US immigration experience.

All Headings:
H1: Frustrating O-1 application turned visa success

H3: Accompanied and supported through the O-1 visa application

Main Content: Frustrating O-1 application turned visa success THE COMPLEX AND STRESSFUL EXPERIENCE OF US IMMIGRATION APPLYING FOR AN O-1 VISA Frustrating O-1 application turned visa success Contributor Tukki Reading time 4 mins read Date published Aug 22, 2024 When Akrisht Pandey , started his pursuit of an O-1 visa, he was no stranger to the challenges of visa applications. As Director of Real Estate at Casas KREA , he had previously worked with his company's lawyer to navigate the complexities of H-1B and O-1 visas, in addition to assisting with visas for his companyâ€™s construction workers. That initial process was anything but smooth. Complex and stressful O-1 visa application process The problems began with poor documentation control. Akrisht had diligently compiled all the necessary documents, categorically organizing them according to the lawyers' requests. However, â€œonly as the application deadline approached did the lawyers begin communicating, asking for the same documents that had already been submitted,â€ Akrisht tells us. This led to delays and stress, as the legal team seemed to lose track of the materials Akrisht had already provided. One particularly frustrating experience involved a visa application for a worker that should have been straightforward: it was a TN visa and required only basic documents, such as a resume, a letter of offer, and a brief explanation of the worker's skills and the company's needs. Despite submitting these documents well in advance, the lawyers informed Akrisht just days before the visa interview that the offer letter format was incorrect , requiring a last-minute revision. The repeated miscommunications, last-minute changes, and general lack of organization from the legal team left Akrisht overwhelmed and frustratedâ€”as it would any visa applicant. â€œJust applying for that was very, very stressful. I was spending more time applying for people's visas than I was working on my own job, â€ says Akrisht. When the time came to apply for his own O-1 visa application, the experience managing othersâ€™ visas made him question whether this legal team was the right fit. The O-1 visas require even more rigorous documentation and proof of qualifications, and need to be entrusted to true pros. Going it alone: Worth the effort? Akrisht had also tried to manage some visa applications independently in the past, particularly with his F1 student visa. For example, one critical payment required for the visa process was mentioned only in a single line on the website. The payment had to be made through a separate website, managed by a different department, and proof of payment needed to be brought to the visa appointmentâ€¦ â€œWhy can't they put everything in one place?!â€ marvels Akrisht. This lack of clarity had led to several of Akrishtâ€™s acquaintances being rejected at their visa appointments, exacerbating the sense that a successful visa process would be impossible alone . â€œFor the F1 visa, there are some forums sharing recommendations of what you can submit and take to interviews, but thereâ€™s nothing like that for the O-1,â€ explains Akrisht. While it might be feasible to handle a student visa on his own, securing an O-1 visaâ€”a much more complex and documentation-heavy processâ€”would require professional help. Accompanied and supported through the O-1 visa application Recognizing the need for a more reliable and supportive legal team, Akrisht was referred to Tukki, including our expert lawyers. From the very beginning, the difference in approach was evident. â€œI got my O-1 visa approved thanks to the team at Tukki and their lawyers were amazing, a really good process. The team did everything to the best of their ability.â€ Unlike his previous experiences, Akrisht felt supported throughout the entire application process. The team worked closely with him to gather and organize all the necessary evidence, emphasizing the importance of thorough and accurate documentation. They were proactive in their communication, addressing any potential issues well before they could become problems. This level of attention and professionalism gave Akrisht confidence that his application was in good hands. Even in moments of doubt, Akrisht appreciated the transparency and honesty of the team at Tukki. They made it clear that while they would do everything in their power to present the strongest possible case, the outcome would ultimately depend on the sufficiency of the evidence provided. This straightforward communication helped manage expectations and reduce stress, allowing Akrisht to focus on gathering the best possible documentation for his application. The successful O-1 visa outcome We have a happy ending! Akrisht was approved for his O-1 visa, a significant achievement that he credits to the exceptional support he received from Tukkiâ€™s legal team. The difference in his experience with this team compared to his previous attempts was night and day. Where other lawyers had caused stress and confusion, Ramiro's team provided clarity, support, and effective guidance. Akrishtâ€™s case highlights the importance of working with a knowledgeable and attentive legal team when navigating the US immigration processes. He learned the hard way that trying to manage such a process alone, or with inadequate support, can lead to unnecessary stress and potential failure. Weâ€™re thrilled that with the right team by his side, he was able to secure his visa with the premium experience curated by Tukki. WE CAN HELP Need more clarity? Find quick answers to frequent visa questions from our legal experts How much documentation do I need to file a visa petition for an EB-1A or O-1A visa? In US immigration processes, your claims must be more likely than not to be true. This means if something appears more true than false, USCIS should accept it as true. To meet this standard, the visa petitioner should provide documents that convincingly support the claimâ€™s validity. For instance, to prove you received VC funding, you could provide signed SAFE agreements with a VC, a published article about your funding round, and documentation about the relevance of the VC. Keep in mind that theory and practice do not always perfectly align. Itâ€™s crucial you speak to an experienced legal team to avoid spending time and money on documentation that does not support your case. Can my company sponsor me for an O-1A if I hold equity in it? According to recent USCIS policy, yes. In general, the agency requires a legitimate employer-employee relationship, which typically involves the ability to â€œhire, pay, fire, supervise, or otherwise control the workâ€ of the beneficiary. Since this policy is new and USCIS has provided little guidance, it remains unclear how these requirements will be applied in the O-1 context. Can the spouses of O-1 visa holders work? No. Spouses of O-1 visa holders receive an O-3 visa, which allows them to live in the U.S. but not to work. They can study, get a driverâ€™s license, open a bank account, and travel in and out of the country freely, but employment is not permitted. What are the typical questions in the O-1 consular interview? Questions vary, but the most common is: â€œTell me why you are extraordinary?â€ Be ready with a concise summary of your accomplishments. This is the time to confidently highlight your achievements, not to be modest. You should also be prepared to explain the details of your U.S. jobâ€”your duties, employer, compensation, and location. How long does it take to get an O-1 visa approved? With premium processing, most O-1 petitions are decided within 15 business days. Without premium processing, a decision can take several months, depending on USCIS workload. The preparation stageâ€”collecting evidence, drafting recommendation letters, and organizing the petitionâ€”typically takes anywhere from 6 weeks to 6 months, depending on the applicantâ€™s profile, the attorneyâ€™s approach, and how quickly supporting documents are provided.
